8a30469b-4012-4f39-aa29-12820dd51b33.title: Russia's war on Ukraine latest news: Zelenskiy warns of more attacks on energy infrastructure By Reuters
8a30469b-4012-4f39-aa29-12820dd51b33.description: Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskiy speaks during a joint news conference with Czech Prime Minister Petr Fiala (not seen), as Russia's attack on Ukraine continues, in Kyiv, Ukraine October 31, 2022.

stories.body:
Nov 7 (Reuters) - Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskiy warned against more potential Russian attacks on energy infrastructure, while the mayor of Kyiv urged residents to consider preparing to leave temporarily if the capital lost water and power supplies.

* U.S. national security adviser Jake Sullivan has held undisclosed talks with top Russian officials in hopes of reducing the risk the war in Ukraine spills over or escalates into a nuclear conflict, the Wall Street Journal said.

* President Joe Biden's administration is privately encouraging Ukraine´s leaders to signal an openness to negotiate with Russia and drop their public refusal to engage in peace talks unless President Vladimir Putin is removed from power, the Washington Post said.

* German Chancellor Olaf Scholz, under fire for a Friday trip to Beijing with German chief executives, said his joint statement with Chinese President Xi Jinping opposing the use of nuclear weapons in Ukraine had been reason enough for the visit.

* Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskiy spoke with European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen on Sunday to discuss macro-financial aid for Ukraine and further sanctions on Iran, Zelenskiy said.

* Iran acknowledged for the first time that it had supplied drones to Moscow, but said they were sent before the war in Ukraine, where Russia has used them to target power stations and civilian infrastructure.

Russia is suffering heavy losses in "fierce" attacks in Ukraine's eastern Donetsk region and is preparing new assaults on Ukrainian energy infrastructure, Zelenskiy said in nightly video remarks on Sunday.

The Russian-installed administration in Ukraine's Kherson region said on Sunday a number of settlements, including Kherson city, had lost water and power supplies after what it called an act of "sabotage".

Ukraine's army accused Russia on Sunday of the large-scale destruction of civilian vessels moored on the banks of the Dnipro River in the occupied southern region of Kherson that Kyiv's forces are trying to capture.

* Ukraine's Russian-held Nova Kakhovka dam was damaged in shelling by Ukrainian forces, Russian news agencies said on Sunday, citing emergency services, but gave no supporting evidence and Reuters could not immediately verify the reports.

* External power has been restored to Ukraine's Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant two days after it was disconnected from the power grid following damage to high-voltage lines from Russian shelling, the United Nations nuclear watchdog said.

* Georgia is on course to become one of the world's fastest-growing economies this year, following a dramatic influx of more than 100,000 Russians since Moscow's invasion of Ukraine and Vladimir Putin's mobilisation drive to drum up war recruits.

stories.title: Russia's war on Ukraine latest news: Zelenskiy warns of more...

stories.body:
Nov 7 (Reuters) - The Kremlin declined to comment on Monday on a Wall Street Journal report that Washington had held undisclosed talks with top Russian officials about avoiding further escalation in the Ukraine war.

According to the report, U.S. National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan held talks with aides to President Vladimir Putin in the hope of reducing the risk that the war in Ukraine spills over or escalates into a nuclear conflict.

"We have nothing to say about this publication," Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov told reporters.

"Once again I repeat that there are some truthful reports, but for the most part there are reports that are pure speculation," he said, directing people to contact the White House or the paper itself.

He added that while Russia remains "open" to talks, it is unable to negotiate with Kyiv due to the latter's refusal to hold talks with Russia.

Few high-level contacts between U.S. and Russian officials have been made public in recent months as Washington has insisted that any talks on ending the war in Ukraine be held between Moscow and Kyiv. (Reporting by Reuters Editing by Gareth Jones)

c1e450d4-616e-43fd-a611-22917e772eba.title: Ukraine rebuilds navy with combat boats from U.S. aid package
c1e450d4-616e-43fd-a611-22917e772eba.description: (Photo by: FILIPPO MONTEFORTE/AFP via Getty Images)

stories.body:
A Russian and Ukrainian flag fly in the port of Sevastopol in 2014. (Photo by: FILIPPO MONTEFORTE/AFP via Getty Images)
TBILISI, Georgia —- Up against one of the world’s largest fleets, Ukraine’s Navy struggled in the early months of Russia’s invasion. Since Feb.24, Russia has been dominating the waterways that surround Ukraine’s eastern and southern coast. In eight months, the Russian military has secured strategic ports of Mariupol and Berdyansk, which both encircle the Sea of Azov.
But it appears that Ukraine has been rebuilding its navy with the help of the U.S. In June, the Department of Defense announced that it would send 18 “coastal and riverine patrol boats” in the $450 million military assistance package. It included two 35-foot small-unit river craft; six 40-foot maritime combat craft; and 10 Dauntless Sea Ark 34-foot patrol boats.
Ukrainian border guards patrol the Sea of Azov off the city of Mariupol on April 30, 2021. (Photo by ALEKSEY FILIPPOV/AFP via Getty Images)
"This will be helpful in enabling the Ukrainians to defend ... Odessa and other positions along the Black Sea coast," a senior defense official said in a briefing at the Pentagon.
The vessels are small and are not meant to compete directly on the open seas with warships like the Moskva, the Russian Black Sea flagship that Ukrainian forces destroyed with a missile strike early in the war. But the combat boats can execute coastal and river operations.
Russian navy officers line up on the deck as the guided missile cruiser Moskva (Moscow) sails back into a harbour after tracking NATO warships in the Black Sea, in the port of Sevastopol, Crimea November 16, 2021. REUTERS/Alexey Pavlishak
A retired Ukrainian Navy captain, Andrii Ryzhenko, told Yahoo News that every boat can be fitted with machine guns and grenade launchers. “It means they can be used primarily to fight with a similar size boat but not with big combat ships,” said Ryzhenko, speaking from Ukraine.
According to reports, a number of the combat boats are already patrolling the Black Sea. Pictures posted to a Ukrainian defense news site, appear to show U.S. “Defiant” 40-foot boats.
Ukrainian marines look at a Russian ship in Sevastopol bay on March 4, 2014. (Photo by: VIKTOR DRACHEV/AFP via Getty Images)
Designed by the Louisiana-based company Metal Shark, the “40 Defiant” has been created to “address the vulnerabilities of traditional patrol boats” while delivering “substantial increases in capabilities and firepower.”
The latest additions to the Navy will be a boost for Ukraine’s ability to defend its ports and waterways. When Russia invaded and annexed the Crimean peninsula in 2014, it had taken over one of Ukraine’s major ports. At least 75% of Ukraine’s fleet was taken by Russia, according to Defense News. Ukraine was forced to begin rebuilding its navy.
In the coming months, Kyiv is expected to get another 22 boats — totalling 40 boats, Ryzhenko said.

8a32d1d0-07ca-4735-964d-8180674d58df.title: Ukraine Latest: Zelenskiy Wants Iran Punished for Helping Russia
8a32d1d0-07ca-4735-964d-8180674d58df.description:
Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskiy said Iran must be punished for what he called its “complicity in Russian terror” and accused
the regime in Tehran of helping to prolong the war and exacerbate its impact on food and energy supplies.

stories.body:
(Bloomberg) -- Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskiy said Iran must be punished for what he called its “complicity in Russian terror” and accused the regime in Tehran of helping to prolong the war and exacerbate its impact on food and energy supplies.
Most Read from Bloomberg
“If it was not for the Iranian supply of weapons to the aggressor, we would be closer to peace now,” Zelenskiy said Sunday evening in his daily address. Earlier, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen told Zelenskiy on a telephone call that she will this week propose a financial aid package of as much as €18 billion ($17.9 billion) to help cover Ukraine’s needs into next year.
Kyiv and six other regions in northern and central Ukraine are meanwhile facing additional emergency blackouts on Monday due to the growing power shortage following Russian attacks on energy infrastructure.
(See RSAN on the Bloomberg Terminal for the Russian Sanctions Dashboard.)
Key Developments
Impounded Russian Superyachts Are Costing Millions to Maintain

European Gas Prices Drop as Warm Weather Contains Heating Demand

Biden’s Big Oil Feud Ignites Just as World Needs US Crude


On the Ground
Ukrainian forces repelled attacks over the past day near eight settlements in the eastern Donetsk and Luhansk regions, Ukraine’s General Staff said on Facebook. The country’s southern operational command said that three Russian munitions depots and a UAV control station were destroyed. Russian troops shelled the Nikopol district in the Dnipropetrovsk region overnight, local authorities said on Telegram. The UK Ministry of Defence said in its latest intelligence update that “Russia’s continued lack of air superiority is likely exacerbated by poor training, loss of experienced crews, and heightened risks of conducting close air support” and that “this is unlikely to change in the next few months.”
Story continues
(All times CET)
Russian-Occupied Kherson Suffering Power Issues (11 a.m.)
The southern city of Kherson and the surrounding areas are experiencing problems with electricity supply and communications, according to a Ukrainian official for the Russian-occupied region.
Yuriy Sobolevskiy, deputy chairman of the Kherson Regional Council, said in a television interview that forced evacuations are continuing. He also accused Russia of spreading false information about Ukraine apparently planning to blow up a nearby dam, and said Russian forces are laying mines in city infrastructure and looting museums and medical facilities.
Refugees ‘Major Challenge for Germany’ (10:45 a.m.)
German Chancellor Olaf Scholz said that the more than 1 million Ukrainian refugees now registered in Germany are posing a major challenge for cities and municipalities.
In a speech in Berlin, Scholz also referred to an agreement last week with the premiers of Germany’s 16 states to provide an additional €1.5 billion in federal funds this year and next to help cope with the influx.
Georgia Shows Strong Recovery: IMF (10:15 a.m.)
Georgia’s economy has recovered robustly from the Covid-19 pandemic, while adverse spillovers from Russia’s war in Ukraine have had less impact than expected, according to James John, head of mission for the International Monetary Fund.
Economic growth is projected at 10% in 2022, and inflation at 10.5%, with both expected to slow next year, according to an IMF statement. Tourism revenue, a surge in immigration and financial inflows triggered by the war, as well as a rise in transit trade, have lifted growth and fiscal revenues.
Turkey, Asia Buying Banned Russian Coal (9 a.m.)
Europe’s hard ban on Russian coal imports, which came into effect on Aug. 10, has pushed rejected Russian coal cargoes to Turkey, India, China and Africa.
These coal cargoes are being sold at a significant discount compared to similar grade coal from other countries. In September, Turkey imported Russian thermal coal at $199 per metric ton, 23% lower than similar grade coal from Colombia, its next largest supplier. See the full BNEF research report here.
Impounded Russian Superyachts Costing Millions (8:30 a.m.)
Seizing superyachts belonging to Russian oligarchs has been a public relations success for Western governments, but the legal and financial implications are complex.
The vessels cost millions of dollars a year to maintain and some US and European taxpayers are footing the bill:
US, Russia Discussed Avoiding Escalation: WSJ (10:15 p.m.)
US National Security Adviser Jake Sullivan and senior Russian counterparts have held talks in recent months on guarding against the risk of escalation and warn Moscow against using nuclear or other weapons of mass destruction, the Wall Street Journal reported, citing US and allied officials. A settlement of the war in Ukraine wasn’t an aim of the discussions, according to the report.
Most Read from Bloomberg Businessweek
©2022 Bloomberg L.P.

bcfcc2d7-b96c-4519-ac24-cee6396ee16e.title: Kremlin unable to force Ukraine to negotiate: ISW
bcfcc2d7-b96c-4519-ac24-cee6396ee16e.description: However, Moscow will be unable to directly force Kiev to negotiate through nuclear threats, according to a new report released today by the Institute for the Study of War (ISW).

stories.body:
Use of nuclear weapons remains "unlikely"  1 di 1  (ANSA) - BELGRADE, NOV 7 - The Kremlin may engage in further rhetorical nuclear
brinkmanship in order to put pressure on the US and its allies to negotiate with Ukraine. However, Moscow will be unable to directly force Kiev to negotiate through nuclear threats, according to a new report released today by the Institute for the Study of War (ISW). Putin and key Kremlin officials had increased their references to nuclear weapons use since Putin's annexation speech on September 30 and throughout October, most likely to pressure Ukraine into negotiations and reduce Western support for Kyiv. However, ISW continues to believe that Russian use of nuclear weapons in Ukraine is unlikely, and that the Kremlin is currently deescalating its nuclear rhetoric. (ANSA).

e21c56e8-0b89-42c3-a559-6de62a47b303.title: FM provides explanations on using Iran drones in Ukraine war
e21c56e8-0b89-42c3-a559-6de62a47b303.description: "Our relations with Russia are based on neighborliness and mutual interests.

stories.body:
TEHRAN, Nov. 05 (MNA) - Iran's Foreign Minister provided some explanations about the recent media controversy regarding the alleged use of Iranian drones and weapons by Russia in the Ukraine war.

"Our relations with Russia are based on neighborliness and mutual interests. I would like to emphasize here that the fuss made by some western countries that Iran has provided Russia with missiles and drones to help the Ukraine war, claims about the missile part is completely wrong and the drone part is correct. We provided Russia with a small number of drones months before the start of the Ukraine war," told Hossein Amir-Abdollahian to the reporters on Saturday.

"We agreed with the Foreign Minister of Ukraine that if they have any documents that Russia has used Iranian drones in Ukraine [war], they provide it to us. We had such an appointment two weeks ago in a European country and our political and defense delegation went to that European country. But unfortunately, the Ukrainian side did not attend in the last moments. The reason was that the US and some European countries, especially Germany, told Ukraine that while we [West] want to use drones against Iran, you want to drink coffee in a European country!" he added.

The Iranian foreign minister went on to say, "But after that, in a phone conversation last week with the Foreign Minister of Ukraine, we agreed that if there is any document, they will provide us with it, and if the Ukrainian side sticks to its promise, we will be able to examine this issue in the coming days."

"Of course, if it is proven to us that Russia used Iranian drones in the war against Ukraine, we will not be indifferent to this issue," Amir-Abdollahian underlined, adding, Our position regarding the war in Ukraine is the cessation of the war, the return of the parties to negotiations and the return of the refugees to their homes, and in this direction, the Islamic Republic has made many efforts since the beginning of the war in Ukraine, and these efforts have been at the level of the president and the foreign minister, and continue to do so. We will continue our efforts until the end of the war in Ukraine."

The anti-Iran claims first emerged in July, with US National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan alleging that Washington had received "information" indicating that the Islamic Republic was preparing to provide Russia with "up to several hundred drones, including weapons-capable UAVs on an expedited timeline" for use in the war.

Both Iran and Russia have repeatedly rejected claims that Tehran has provided Moscow with drones to be used in the war in Ukraine.

Iranian Foreign Minister Hossein Amir-Abdollahian in a phone talk with his Ukrainian counterpart Dmytro Kuleba on Friday once again rejected Western countries' allegations of sending drones to Russia for use against Ukraine, saying that Ukraine should be careful not to be influenced by some extreme European politicians.

He said that the foreign policy of the Islamic Republic is completely clear and is based on a single standard which is opposition to the war, adding that Tehran is ready to hold technical meetings with the presence of military experts between the two countries without the need for any intermediaries.

3b08309b-b309-44f6-b793-ec13181afaea.title: Belarus opposition leader urges closer contacts with Ukraine
3b08309b-b309-44f6-b793-ec13181afaea.description: She also complained about the "lack of understanding" of what is happening in Belarus on the part of Ukrainians.

stories.body:
Exiled Belarusian opposition leader Svyatlana Tsikhanowskaya has said in a wide-ranging interview with a popular Ukrainian website that there is a huge difference between the Belarusian people and government. She also complained about the "lack of understanding" of what is happening in Belarus on the part of Ukrainians. According to Tsikhanowskaya, both Ukrainians and Belarusians are fighting against a "common enemy" - Russia. The following is the text of an article by Sevhil Musayeva and Roman Romanyuk, entitled "Svyatlana Tsikhanowskaya: If missiles are launched from Belarus again, Ukraine will have the right to attack in response" and published by the Ukrayinska Pravda website on 3 November; subheadings are as published: 


Very often waves of history bring to the fore people who have not expected such a twist themselves and, moreover, have never imagined themselves to be leaders of nations and masters of destinies of the world.

The story of Svyatlana Tsikhanowskaya is mostly about this. Prior to the tragic and at the same time heroic events of the 2020 Belarusian revolution Svyatlana, to put it mildly, was not the number one political figure in her country. But it has been even more interesting to see Tsikhanowskaya gradually turn under blows of destiny from " a blogger's wife" and housewife into an opposition leader. In spite of the price she had to pay.

"In fact, I have constant discord. Either to speak about my husband only (Syarhey Tsikhanowski has been in prison in Belarus since 2020 - UP [Ukrayinska Pravda]] who is, of course, my closest person. My children ask me every day: 'When will we see our dad?' And you still cannot tell them: guys, dad has been sentenced to 18 years in prison. But it is not my husband only because all the Belarusians who are currently in prison are also my close people," clearly confused Tsikhanowskaya answers the question about how her family has been living through the permanent struggle that began two years ago.

Throughout this period of time the circle of people "close" to her has increased catastrophically. There are 1,350 officially recognised political prisoners in Belarus now.

"But you know, it is even uncomfortable for me to speak about my family now against the background of what is happening in Ukraine where people are killed. Sometimes it seems to me: well, we do not have such a big issue, people are only behind bars. But it is still pain, and you live with it every day," adds Tsikhanowskaya.

Not so long ago Svyatlana published an open letter to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. Its gist boiled down to the need for dialogue between the Ukrainian government and the leaders of free Belarus. According to information available to UP, Zelensky's inner circle has ignored requests for a meeting from the Svyatlana Tsikhanowskaya team. And on the whole, they are treating her activities with caution.

"We are ready to act together with Ukraine. Because without free Ukraine, there will be no free Belarus and Europe. And without free Belarus, there cannot be free Ukraine," Tsikhanowskaya said in her address.

Read in Tsikhanowskaya's interview with Ukrayinska Pravda about how Ukraine should not lose contacts with the people of Belarus, why the people and Lukashenka are not the same, whether Belarusians are ashamed of their regime helping Russia kill Ukrainians and why President Volodymyr Zelensky has not responded to Tsikhanowskaya's address.
'Belarus has become a co-aggressor. And immediately they began treating all Belarusians in the same way'


[UP] Not so long ago you published an open letter to Volodymyr Zelensky. Its main message was the idea of cooperation in the future. Why did you decide to come up with the proposal just now, in the eighth month of the all-out war?

[Tsikhanowskaya] In fact, I recorded another address to the Ukrainian people and President Zelensky right after the war broke out. At the time we took a clear stance on support for Ukraine, underlined that one should differentiate between the Belarusian regime and the Belarusian people, that we were on your side. We wanted to convey this idea to Ukrainians and the administration [presidential office], first of all.

You know, I was also a little shocked and surprised that [Ukrainians'] stance on Belarusians dramatically changed after the war began. We used to live in the same world, in the world of revolution, a negative stance on the regime and wanted to topple this regime, and it seemed to us that Ukrainians, our closest allies, fully understood what was going on.

And then the war began, and we understood that people in Ukraine do not have the slightest idea about our struggle, about thousands of people in prisons, have no idea that the number of political prisoners grows every day. We had to rediscover Belarusians and Belarus for Ukrainians. It was very difficult given the emotional background, given that Belarus became a co-aggressor in the eyes of Ukrainians. And they immediately began to treat all Belarusians in the same way.

[UP] Ukrainians actively supported Belarusians when protests broke out. But it seems to me that the current reaction is such because there was practically no protest wave in Belarus against the war in Ukraine. Only some figures, some artists voiced their positions. And if protests are suppressed inside the country, what prevented Belarusians from holding rallies in other European cities?

[Tsikhanowskaya] Our Belarusian diaspora became engaged in the Ukrainian agenda, Belarusians took part in mass protests with Ukrainians in various cities.

As for Belarus, again, it is a misunderstanding, and Ukrainians did not follow developments that thousands of people had been in prison and hundreds of thousands had left Belarus before the war began. It was the result of the level of fear, when people were sentenced to 15-20 years in prison for an anti-regime message.

You cannot say that there were no protests. On 27 February, and it may have gone unnoticed, thousands of Belarusians held protests against the war in various cities of Belarus. People knew what they were risking, that they would be imprisoned for that, but they still took to the streets because it was important for them to show Belarusians' stance on the war.

Of course, one would like to see mass protests. But our experience in the past year and a half has shown that when you hoist a Ukrainian flag on a building or write in a comment "no to war" or "Lukashenka is a war criminal", you immediately end up in prison for many, many years. It constricts people.

In spite of this, people are making small steps, something they can do in this situation.

Due to our partisans [so-called railway partisans who damaged railway equipment in Belarus to prevent the movement of Russian personnel and materiel in the country], I hope very much, we have made at least that small contribution at the time, and Russian forces did not manage to invade Ukraine as fast as they hoped to, let me say. They were tasked with capturing Kyiv in three days. I do hope that this contribution by Belarusians had had some effect.

And we also understand that people were ready to take to the streets, but they would be simply imprisoned. And what would happen next? It would be a scorched field, scorched earth of Belarus.

How can we help Ukraine at least in some way in this situation? We do not have a state at the moment.

Because the state is occupied, the regime has become a co-aggressor in this war, Putin's collaborator. But even in spite of this Belarusians are helping Ukrainian refugees with those scarce means they have. So many Belarusians have remained in Ukraine to help Ukrainians. Our medics helped the military and civilians there.

You cannot underestimate the importance of information. When not only Belarusian but also Russian propaganda peddles the narrative that there are Nazis in Ukraine, and we have to counter this agenda and tell Belarusians what is going on indeed, and our independent media have been declared extremist and terrorist, it is very very difficult to reach out to the audience. But we understand how important it is. And at the same time, we have to remember the Belarusians who are behind bars, who are being beaten up and raped in prisons. The task is difficult.

I am not saying at all that we, so to speak, have one common problem. Because what is going on in Ukraine is simply beyond comprehension. But we have the common enemy. And Belarusian democratic society, Belarusians are fighting not only against the regime but also against the Russian occupation.

[UP] If Belarus officially enters the war, will it become a reason for people to take to the streets? Do I understand it correctly that this is what Lukashenka is afraid of?

[Tsikhanowskaya] You know, when they say that "Belarus will not enter the war officially", I am somewhat surprised. Because the Lukashenka regime has officially entered this war already.

When we speak about the Belarusian army, I think that there was a higher likelihood of the Belarusian forces entering the war in February, when Lukashenka was so convinced in the blitzkrieg, just like Putin and the Kremlin. But even at the time it was clear that there was no anti-Ukrainian sentiment in the Belarusian army. Belarusian soldiers were not motivated to fight against Ukrainians.

Moreover, they understood full well that they did not have any operational experience and would be used as cannon fodder. Lukashenka understood this sentiment in the army. At the moment, it is extremely unlikely that such an order will be given. However, if under pressure, Lukashenka, of course, can do that. But the fact that he does not send troops, as you say, officially is not because that he wants to help Ukraine in some way or wants to protect Ukraine by not sending in Belarusian troops. He only cares about his post, about his power. Because, to tell you the truth, this order would become his political suicide.

And I am more than convinced that if such an order is given, Belarusians will not fight. They will run away, they will surrender immediately, as the I Want to Live campaign [Ukrainian campaign targeting Russian troops and calling on them to surrender] encourages them. We are spreading this information through our social media for our military: "Do contact them at once, do not fight." Do you understand that at the moment it is important for Russia that Ukrainians treat Belarusians with same hatred they treat Russians? We are not your enemies. But of course, there is a high likelihood that Belarus may be used as a bridgehead for military hardware. There have emerged a lot of theories, for example, that Russians would be told to wear Belarusian uniforms in order to show that Belarusians are fighting. Because Putin does not want to be engaged in this war on his own either. We do understand that they are creating the image of an external enemy, are depicting Ukraine as an enemy so that Belarusians begin to treat Ukrainians in the same way. And at the same time, Lukashenka looks like a saviour - you see, we have the Union State [of Belarus and Russia], their troops are here to defend our territory. He has to somehow justify the presence of Russian forces in our territory. And at the moment a kind of covert mobilisation is under way. People are being sent call-up papers, but it is being done very carefully. They are not openly speaking about it on TV in order not to provoke a wave of resistance in Belarus.
'We have neither an army nor weapons either. What shall we fight with?'


[UP] When there were protests in Belarus, one of the protest leaders said the following phrase: "We want a peaceful protest, but we do not want a Maidan [the 2013-14 anti-government pro-EU protests in Ukraine] here." As far as I understand this phrase, you did not want a violent confrontation in the streets. Do you think it is possible to topple the Lukashenka regime without a violent confrontation?

[Tsikhanowskaya] It was Lukashenka who was shouting everywhere: "Do you want developments like in Ukraine? Do you want a Maidan?" He was speaking about the public's willingness to topple the authorities by force. But you remember the situation in Maidan. You also had peaceful protests at first. And I am convinced that you did not want bloodshed. But at the time when the first 100 people were killed, it further boosted Ukrainians' morale...[ellipses as published throughout]

Your police sided with people. And we called on our OMON [OMAP riot police] to side with Belarusians but we, probably, were not quite sure that they would do that. Because for 26 years the regime has been building such a vertical of power that now all these structures of power, all these KGB and other structures are subordinate to Lukashenka. The do not defend the country, they defend one person. On the whole, Belarusians are, as you call us, patient, more law abiding. And we believed that indeed we could secure the change of power peacefully. We had never had such mass protests in Belarus before. And it seemed to us that victory was very close.

Looking back, I probably want to say that our people were not ready for more radical actions at the time. Of course, we had some groups of people who always said that we should be more radical, but it was not a popular idea.

[UP] How possible is at least partial radicalisation of actions at the moment? The regime whose laws you observe has practically brought you to the edge beyond which there is an all-out war. Our missiles can be launched at your bases and it will be absolutely justified on our part. How long can Ukraine put up with all this at the end of the day?

[Tsikhanowskaya] Yes, I understand that if missiles are again launched from Belarusian territory, Ukrainians and Ukraine will have the right to strike back. That is why our task is to prevent Belarusian troops from invading Ukraine.

At the moment there is a wing in our united transitional cabinet which we call armed defence. But it does not mean that we are going to declare war on Belarus and fight. We have neither an army nor weapons. What can we fight with? We do not have such capabilities, given that thousands of Russian soldiers are still in Belarus and they will be ready to defend Lukashenka. At the moment a lot of men are undergoing military training, also using friendly relations with other neighbouring states. All this causes stress for the regime. They understand what is going on. And the same the Peramoha plan on which [opposition] law enforcers who quit the structures in 2020 are currently working is not about violence either. It is about a blockade of some important strategic facilities. But it is also a message to our army that if an order is given, you will have a venue in Ukraine, contacts of people you can join, how you can defect and point your weapons at those who are still backing Lukashenka militarily.

Therefore, it must be too early to speak about how it will be done in Belarus. Our current task is to prepare for the moment when we feel Lukashenka's weakness. He is weak already but I am saying that the critical moment when all of us act as a united force on all the fronts has not come yet.

[UP] A year ago you said in an interview with Yevropeyska Pravda that the Lukashenka regime could fall in the spring. Now we can see that everything is getting worse: Lukashenka is semi-involved in the war and fully dependent on Putin. And as far as I understand, people in Belarus are also intimidated and there is no hope for protests. Do you still believe that the Lukashenka regime will fall soon? And actually, what is his regime based on at the moment?

[Tsikhanowskaya] The regime rests on three pillars. These are money, law enforcers and support from Putin. This is what enabled him to cling on to power in 2020, too. And I am more than convinced that when we sense this moment, there will be both mass protests and the Peramoha plan will be activated.

Army volunteers will also play their role in this in some way. They are currently fighting shoulder to shoulder with Ukrainians in this war against the Russian aggression. Therefore, you cannot rule the mass involvement of Belarusians either.

But you see, people in the country have preserved this energy inside in spite of being intimidated, in spite of being afraid every day that law enforcers will raid their homes, throw them face down on the floor, will blackmail them with their families and children.

Lukashenka has failed to turn this page of history and win back the public.

He is afraid of holding referendums, he is afraid of any gatherings and elections to local state agencies. It threatens him with a mass uprising. Therefore, I believe in Belarusians , I see that their passion has not gone anywhere.

[UP] Are you saying that everyone is waiting for the right time?

[Tsikhanowskaya] It is not called waiting for the right time. It is called working for the sake of taking full advantage of this moment.
'Belarusians also ask the question: 'Why are you not standing together with Zelensky yet? Why is there no joint photo?'


[UP] You appealed to Zelensky in your column. Have there been any contacts with you on his part?

[Tsikhanowskaya] If we speak about the highest level, the president, Ukraine's stance on communication with the democratic forces of Belarus is very cautious because in the state of war any wrong step, as it seems to the Zelensky administration, may cause reckless steps on the part of Lukashenka. But the war will end anyway, and it will end with Ukraine's victory. And now, without establishing contacts with democratic Belarus, [they risk that] Belarusians can be of an opinion that Ukraine is ready to further cooperate with Lukashenka who is the same aggressor [as Putin].

[UP] Ukraine has not recognised Lukashenka as the president since 2020.

[Tsikhanowskaya] Then why do they not communicate with those Belarusians who see their future as pro-European and pro-democratic? And Belarusians also ask the question: "Why are you not standing together with Zelensky yet? Why is there no join photo?" But it is not about this meeting or a photo. It is about what happens prior to this meeting. We have established contacts at the highest level with the Supreme Council [parliament] and Zelensky's advisers. We have an office working in Kyiv. It also means establishing reliable relations. Because I can see narratives that "Tsikhanowskaya is an FSB agent", that she once spoke about "wise Putin" being spread in the Ukrainian segment of social media and in Ukraine on the whole.

This point is being belaboured. They are trying to picture the democratic forces in the negative light, saying that they are not pro-Ukrainian enough or not pro-European enough.

But have repeatedly and openly said that we are on the side of Ukraine, that we are for a democratic future and called for building relations because we will still have to live together. It is also important for us to see that Putin will fail to set us against one another, that we are not enemies. Therefore, it is not about a photo but about what is going in the understanding between the two nations: Belarusians and Ukrainians.

[UP] As for you, I have asked both the presidential office and MPs of the pro-presidential faction why they actually do not want to establish dialogue with Tsikhanowskaya and new Belarus. There is no doubt that there is an obstacle - your statement you made back in 2020 on Crimea when you said that Crimea is Ukrainian de jure but Russian de facto. It is a painful issue for us and we cannot forgive anyone for it, even in spite of you having repeatedly said afterwards that Crimea is Ukraine.

[Tsikhanowskaya] It is the easiest thing to do - to trade accusations. I can hear Belarusians who also have a lot of complaints [about the Belarusian opposition]. When I see these altercations, when Belarusians and Ukrainians are fighting for something, I understand that this is the result of the work of Russian propaganda. It is very important for the Russians that we fall out with you, that we are locked in conflicts and then it would be great for them.

It is not the right time to sort things out now. Now is the time to cooperate because we have a common enemy. Our enemy is the Russian Empire, and we need to get out of its influence. What is going on in Ukraine cannot be compared with political repression in Belarus. We cannot compare them a priori. We saw what happened in Bucha, we saw what happened in Mariupol. Do you think we are not ashamed of and it does not hurt us that Ukraine was attacked for Belarusian territory? How many casualties have there been due to missiles launched from Belarusian territory? Of course, we are ashamed! And we understand that we may have underperformed, underdelivered in 2020. We can say that there was little support. But it is also our fault and we feel guilty. But you cannot develop when you feel guilty. We have to learn to speak, learn to share our common pain. The most important thing at the moment is not to have our nations divided, not to become enemies of each other. This is the most terrible thing that may happen. Lukashenka understands that if he retains power, it will mean a blanket isolation of Belarusians. There will be thousands of kilometres of constant fear. I do hope that Ukrainians who have praised Lukashenka all these years because they did not understand what was going on will never return to the narrative "there are clean streets and tasty milk in Belarus".

[UP] I come from Volyn Region, and we have always envied Belarus exactly because of "clean streets and tasty milk".

[Tsikhanowskaya] And Ukrainians credited Lukashenka for that. They did not credit Belarusians. According to them, it was Lukashenka who allegedly milked cows and cleaned streets.

[UP] But at the moment people in Volyn have been anticipating for several months a tank invasion from Belarus. They see missiles and drones flying from there. There is no envy left, only anger. There is so much contempt for the Russians that it will suffice for future generations. But how can we save relations with Belarusians?

[Tsikhanowskaya] I believe that the mass media have a great impact on the public sentiment, as well as the narratives they use. Russian and Belarusian propaganda has invested a lot of money to force our people to fall out with each other. You need to try to understand Belarusians. I understand that it is hard to do now because when missiles fall on your head, it is difficult to answer the question: "Belarusians, why do you not take to the streets?" To understand this, one has to look back many years and understand how this dictatorship was built in our country. To understand that Ukraine as a nation, unlike Belarusians, has made much bigger progress because our identity was trampled on and destroyed. I believe that you made a breakthrough after 2004. And we have something to look up to. Because what happened in you country is only just starting in ours, let me put it this way. Our eyes have just opened to how important a national identity is.

And therefore, you have to explain patiently what happened in Belarus and why Belarusians currently have no possibility to hold mass protests. To explain that Belarusians are on the side of Ukraine.

I understand it when Western states think that if there is a protest, people are "against", and if there is no protest, people are "for".

I believe that nevertheless Ukrainians understand Belarusians more and do not spread these miserable propaganda narratives that "Belarusians are for Lukashenka", that Belarusians are silent punching bags. There is no huge money behind us, we cannot supply you with the HIMARS. But when they were collecting money for a Bayraktar [UAV] in Poland, Belarusians made the biggest part of people who made donations. We have very little money. People are pinching off money from their salaries to help Ukraine, to help refugees. This is what we can do, but we do it from the bottom of our hearts.

[UP] Could you tell us if you keep in touch with the Kalinowski regiment[ Belarusian volunteer unit fighting within the ranks of the Ukrainian army]?

[Tsikhanowskaya] Of course. We have an office in Kyiv, and the permanent representative of the Kalinowski regiment is working there. He is responsible for international relations. They maintain contacts with us.

We have a person whom I cannot name, and he is acting as liaison between the Kalinowski regiment and other Belarusian formations and democratic forces. We are very proud of Belarusians who are fighting alongside Ukrainians. They are our heroes, I would say that to some extent they are saving the face of Belarusians in this war. And I have heard great appreciation of the courage and bravery of our volunteers. And I welcome the fact that, without having their own training centres, they secured other states' permissions to be trained there. Because demand for training is growing, more and more men realise that they have to defend Belarus now through defending Ukraine.

[UP] And what is your stance on some Ukrainian MPs, including those of the [ruling] Servant of the People party, willing to develop some political plans with the Kalinowski regiment, speaking about future with them but not you? Because they believe that the military elite of Belarus are the people who have the right to reform and speak about a new Belarus.

[Tsikhanowskaya] First of all, I am happy that they are establishing contacts with the Kalinowski regiment and that they had a meeting at the Supreme Council. It is a sign of a high assessment by Ukrainian authorities of the contribution the Belarusian volunteers have made into the future victory of Ukrainians over the aggressor. The volunteers who are currently fighting in Ukraine must have the right and the possibility to build a new Belarus. If some of them have political ambitions and some political leaders are emerging, of course, it will be the right of Belarusians to elect their future authorities and a future president. And if such plans are comfortable for the Ukrainian side at the moment, we only welcome them.

[UP] Are you conducting systemic work with the armed forces in Belarus? Is there a possibility to communicate with people and understand the real atmosphere in the regular army?

[Tsikhanowskaya] Given the conditions we are in we have to be very creative. Because the Belarusian forces, soldiers are isolated from the outer world to a large degree. It is being done deliberately so that, as the regime puts it, "destructive elements" have no impact on them.

Of course, there are soldiers in army circles, even senior officers, who are constantly sharing insider information with us. They tell us what is going on, share some documents concerning the army and also speak about developments in the country.

And soldiers themselves, via Telegram channels, either Belaruski Hayun [open-source intelligence project] or some others they trust, report information about how they are being informed about this war or are preparing for some war crimes.

At the moment, everything is quiet there, they appear to be saying: "Do not worry, Belarus will not enter the war." They are lulling and calming them down. But of course, all of them are on alert, they understand what is going on. And they are meeting their relatives who can tell them something. It is very difficult for them to have permanent communication channels. They are being monitored very strictly and cut off immediately if found.

Information is conveyed, first of all, through public statements. And our representative for defence Valeryy Sakhashchyk (a retired Belarusian army officer, a member of the united transitional cabinet led by Svyatlana Tsikhanowskaya - UP) is, in my opinion, a very good achievement. The military and KGB officers may have decided against joining us in 2020 because they did not have a beacon, a person who could speak the same language as they did. And Sakhashchyk enjoys a very high authority among the military. He gets a lot of information. Of course, not all of it can be shared. But I would say that contacts have become more stable.

[UP] Are you ready to come to Kyiv and under what conditions can it happen? 

[Tsikhanowskaya] I am ready to arrive in Kyiv when the Kyiv side is ready to accept me.

[UP] Are you speaking about President Zelensky when you say the Kyiv side?

[Tsikhanowskaya] His administration.

[UP] So are you not ready to come just to support Ukrainians?

[Tsikhanowskaya] Look, the situation with me is a little more complicated. Our representatives can arrive. But you have to understand that I am under protection of the Lithuanian state. And for me to be able to travel to Kyiv the Lithuanian side has to ensure my security. Because I have a diplomatic status here. And until there is no official invitation from the president or the prime minister, they simply cannot organise this visit.

This is the situation I am in. It is not that simple that I could decide and travel anywhere. It is not a must to organise my personal meeting [with the Ukrainian leadership]. It may be a multilateral meeting, as part of a certain delegation form Lithuania or Poland or Estonia. I think our political allies would be happy to arrange it. But in this case there still must be an official request.

[UP] Thank you. We are not the presidential office, but we invite you to visit Kyiv.

[Tsikhanowskaya] Glory to Ukraine!

[UP] Long live Belarus!




Source: Ukrayinska Pravda website, Kyiv, in Ukrainian 0330 gmt 3 Nov 22

sentences:
Exiled Belarusian opposition leader Svyatlana Tsikhanowskaya has said in a wide-ranging interview with a popular Ukrainian website that there is a huge difference between the Belarusian people and government.
Read in Tsikhanowskaya's interview with Ukrayinska Pravda about how Ukraine should not lose contacts with the people of Belarus, why the people and Lukashenka are not the same, whether Belarusians are ashamed of their regime helping Russia kill Ukrainians and why President Volodymyr Zelensky has not responded to Tsikhanowskaya's address.
[Tsikhanowskaya] If we speak about the highest level, the president, Ukraine's stance on communication with the democratic forces of Belarus is very cautious because in the state of war any wrong step, as it seems to the Zelensky administration, may cause reckless steps on the part of Lukashenka.
The following is the text of an article by Sevhil Musayeva and Roman Romanyuk, entitled "Svyatlana Tsikhanowskaya: If missiles are launched from Belarus again, Ukraine will have the right to attack in response" and published by the Ukrayinska Pravda website on 3 November; subheadings are as published: 


Very often waves of history bring to the fore people who have not expected such a twist themselves and, moreover, have never imagined themselves to be leaders of nations and masters of destinies of the world.

[Tsikhanowskaya] Our Belarusian diaspora became engaged in the Ukrainian agenda, Belarusians took part in mass protests with Ukrainians in various cities.

stories.title: Belarus opposition leader urges closer contacts with Ukraine

0d376d81-0bbc-41d4-b0d2-a7150f07e6d1.title: Ukraine looks to technology to help rebuild its economy after Russia's invasion
0d376d81-0bbc-41d4-b0d2-a7150f07e6d1.description: “I don't think there's something in the world that could kill our ability to win and ability to do work or anything,” Valery Krasovsky, CEO and co-founder of Sigma Software, told CNBC on the sidelines of the Web Summit tech conference in Lisbon.

stories.body:
LISBON, PORTUGAL — As the war in Ukraine rages on, the country's technology entrepreneurs are trying to stay positive.
 “I don't think there's something in the world that could kill our ability to win and ability to do work or anything,” Valery Krasovsky, CEO and co-founder of Sigma Software, told CNBC on the sidelines of the Web Summit tech conference in Lisbon.  Sigma, which has 2,000 employees based in Ukraine, equipped its offices with diesel generators and Starlink internet terminals to allow employees to continue working amid Russian shelling of critical energy infrastructure.  “Nothing could happen that would stop us delivering business, even in these conditions,” he added.  Sigma was one of 59 Ukrainian start-ups that attended the event last week. Ukraine had a notable presence at Web Summit, where it sought support from the global tech community to bolster its fight against Russia.  In 2021, Ukraine had a small booth at Web Summit, Krasovsky said. This year, it had a much larger stand, lit up in yellow and blue. It was surrounded by floods of visitors, with Ukraine's first lady Olena Zelenska — accompanied by armed guards as she passed through the venue — among them.  On the opening night, Zelenska made an impassioned speech calling on tech entrepreneurs and investors to aid her country.  “You are the force that moves the world,” Zelenska, the wife of Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, told a packed audience Tuesday.  Whereas Russia uses technology for “terror,” the international community has “technologies that can help, not destroy,” she added.  Russia has called its invasion a “special military operation.” To Ukraine, however, it is an unprovoked land grab aimed at undermining its sovereignty.  Rebuilding with technology  Ukrainan officials and entrepreneurs said tech would be key in helping the country rebuild after Russia's invasion.  Moscow began its invasion of Ukraine in February and the war has decimated the country's economy. Its gross domestic product has shrunk by 30% so far this year, according to figures from the economy ministry.  The World Bank estimates that Ukraine's gross domestic product will contract 45% during the whole of 2022.  “People inside Kyiv and some other cities, they're building, they're making business, they're still exporting,” Dima Shvets, CEO and co-founder of Ukrainian social media startup Reface, told CNBC.  Shvets runs Reface remotely from London, where he lives with his wife and their four-year-old daughter. Around half of his near-200 person team continue to work in Ukraine. When the bombing starts, people use the basement of Reface's Ukraine outpost as a shelter to hide.  Reface has rented a hotel for 50 people in the Western part of Ukraine with separate infrastructure for electricity so they can continue to work safely, Shvets said. It has tried to “organically” relocate workers to Portugal, he added — but convincing them to leave has been difficult.  “People have houses, families in Ukraine,” he said.  In an interview with CNBC's Karen Tso , Ukraine's first lady said it was “impossible to underestimate” the role of technology in Ukraine.  Watch CNBC's full interview with Ukrainian first lady Olena Zelenska  “In this situation, it's hard to talk about sustainability, technology, progress, since we're just trying to hold on and live our lives as normal as possible,” Zelenska said. “Still, we have lots of startups, and I hope that all the ideas presented at this summit can push us to victory.”  As winter approaches, however, Ukraine will need more than just IT investment to see it through the harsh months ahead.  There have been reports of widespread power blackouts lasting several hours across the country. Around 40% of Ukraine's energy system has been destroyed, according to the government.  “Ukraine needs more weapons, more military assistance,” Zelenska said, calling specifically for air defense missiles.  Capital is coming  Ukraine's IT industry brought in $2 billion of revenue in the first quarter of 2022, according to the National Bank of Ukraine, an increase of 28% year-on-year despite the devastation caused by Russia's invasion.  The war has displaced millions of Ukrainians, including technology professionals. Many have joined roles overseas . Once the fighting ends, it is hoped that those workers will return.  Some companies are ramping up hiring in Ukraine in a bet that the country's tech industry will emerge stronger after the war ends.  Two months ago, Lithuanian VPN software firm Nord Security opened an office in the western Ukrainian city of Lviv. The company plans to hire 100 people there, according to CEO Tom Okman.  “We think it's time to build back Ukraine and we think the talent there is great,” Okman told CNBC.  He noted Ukraine is home to thousands of skilled software programmers and engineers. “Just think how many American companies have IT outsourcing” in Ukraine, he said.  Several founders of billion-dollar “unicorns” come from Ukraine, including Grammarly's Max Lytvyn and Alex Shevchenko and GitLab's Dmitriy Zaporozhets. Google Samsung and Amazon also have research and development centers in the country.  But there are challenges beyond the war facing Ukraine's tech ecosystem. The country's venture landscape is still emerging. Startups in the country attracted only $22 million so far this year, according to Dealroom data.  “There are no big inflows in capital to support what we do,” Reface's Shvets said. “What we should do properly now is show more examples of entrepreneurship.”  Shvets said the government in Ukraine should look to assist local entrepreneurs in the country with tax incentives and other pro-business initiatives.  There are signs that sentiment from tech investors to Ukraine is improving, though. Last month, Horizon Capital, a Kyiv-based VC firm, raised $125 million for a startup fund aimed at backing Ukrainian founders.  SID Venture Partners, a venture fund set up by Sigma and fellow Ukrainian tech firms Ideasoft and Datrics, has so far invested in 10 startups with Ukrainian founders, Krasovsky said.  It plans to raise an additional $50 to $60 million from institutional investors after raising an initial $15 million in December 2021. “There's huge interest,” Krasovsky said.
